p: In May 2004, heatwave and droughts were observed in the coastal areas of Kenya, towards Lamu and Mombasa, two large coastal cities. That period was also the beginning of a large outbreak of chikungunya in these two cities (with reported attack rates of 75 %) prior to its spread to the Indian Ocean [ 7]. Entomologists have explained how and why droughts can be associated with increases in Aedes-borne diseases, such as chikungunya, as well as dengue, Zika and yellow fever [ 8]. During droughts, due to water scarcity, people are prone to store larger amount of water, outside, in the shadow of their house, for longer time periods, providing shelters to mosquitos’ eggs and larvae.
